tn.text: This chapter describes the final war for the city of Jerusalem and how God will save her.

tn.ref: your plunder will be divided in your midst
tn.text: AT: "your enemies will take all of your possessions and divide it for themselves while you watch" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: I will gather every nation against Jerusalem for battle
tn.text: AT: "I will cause many nations to attack Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: the remainder of the people will not be cut off from the city
tn.text: AT: "your enemies will allow the remaining people to stay in the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
These verses continue the description of the final war for the city of Jerusalem and of how God will save her.

tn.ref: as when he wages war on the day of battle
tn.text: AT: "just as he battled in the past"

tn.ref: his feet will stand on the Mount of Olives
tn.text: "His feet" refers to Yahweh himself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These verses continue the description of the final war for the city of Jerusalem and of how God will save her.
This is the name of a town or village east of Jerusalem. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This probably refers to God's angels.
These verses continue the description of the final war for the city of Jerusalem and of how God will save her.
This normally means running or flowing water, rather than still or stagnant water. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This refers to the Dead Sea, which is east of Jerusalem.
This refers to the Mediterranean Sea.
These verses continue the description of the final war for the city of Jerusalem and of how God will save her.

tn.ref: there will be Yahweh, the one God, and his name alone
tn.text: "there will only be one God, Yahweh, who will be worshiped." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hendiadys]])
These are the names of places. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Jerusalem will continue to be raised up
tn.text: This refers to the altitude of the city of Jerusalem, about 760 meters above sea level.

tn.ref: the Benjamin Gate ... the first gate ... the Corner Gate
tn.text: These are names of various gates in the city wall of Jerusalem.
This refers to a strong point in the city defenses on the wall. It was probably built by a man named Hananel.
This probably refers to the place where wine was made for the royal family.
These verses continue the description of the final war for the city of Jerusalem and of how God will save her.
AT: "walking around"

tn.ref: the hand of one will be raised up against the hand of another
tn.text: Each person will attack another. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These verses continue the description of the final war for the city of Jerusalem and of how God will save her.

tn.ref: Judah will also fight against Jerusalem
tn.text: Some versions read, "Judah will also fight for Jerusalem." The Hebrew text is uncertain.
AT: "They will capture the possessions"
"in great quantities"
These verses continue the description of the final war for the city of Jerusalem and of how God will save her.
AT: "that attacked Jerusalem"
AT: "will severely punish the nations"
These verses continue the description of the final war for the city of Jerusalem and of how God will save her.

tn.ref: will be like the bowls before the altar
tn.text: AT: "will be as sacred as the bowls used at the altar"

tn.ref: every pot in Jerusalem and Judah will be dedicated to Yahweh of hosts
tn.text: Various types of pots and utensils were made especially to be used in the temple for the worship of Yahweh and for the sacrifices. These were considered special, not to be used for anything else.

tn.ref: Traders will no longer be in the house of Yahweh
tn.text: It was the custom for traders to sell the people things they needed in order to make proper sacrifices to Yahweh in the temple. Some versions translated "Canaanites" instead, because the Hebrew text may have a double meaning: "traders" and "Canaanites."
